events.description: Banco de México decided to hold the policy rate at 7.00% and signaled caution on future easing.
A rebound in domestic growth during the fourth quarter.
A period of strong appreciation for the Mexican peso in January.

facts.fact_text: Banco de México held the policy rate at 7.00%.

evidences.evidence_text: Banco de México’s decision to hold the policy rate at 7.00%

facts.fact_text: The Mexican peso retreated past 17.40 per US dollar.

evidences.evidence_text: Mexican peso retreated past 17.40 per US dollar

facts.fact_text: Banxico revised its inflation path higher through 2026.

evidences.evidence_text: revised its inflation path higher through 2026

claims.claim_text: Real yield support for the peso will narrow only slowly.
claims.author: Market expectations

evidences.evidence_text: reinforcing expectations that real yield support will narrow only slowly rather than remain firmly anchored

claims.claim_text: The peso is vulnerable to external pressure from a firmer US dollar and elevated US yields.

evidences.evidence_text: the peso remained vulnerable to external pressure as a firmer US dollar and elevated US yields continued to raise the opportunity cost of peso exposure

claims.claim_text: Domestic growth remains modest despite a recent rebound.

evidences.evidence_text: evidence that growth remains modest despite a Q4 rebound

claims.claim_text: Trade-related uncertainty and modest growth capped the peso's upside.

evidences.evidence_text: lingering trade related uncertainty capped upside

evidence.evidence_text: Mexican peso retreated past 17.40 per US dollar giving back part of its recent gains, as markets digested Banco de México’s decision
Banxico acknowledged firmer inflation risks... and emphasised graduality
elevated US yields continued to raise the opportunity cost of peso exposure
lingering trade related uncertainty capped upside
